concept.title: How to read syntax diagrams
concept.shortdesc: Learn how to read syntax diagrams.

ul.li: If punctuation marks, parentheses, arithmetic operators, or other such symbols are shown, enter them as part of the syntax.

Required items appear on the horizontal line (the main path). <syntaxdiagram> <groupseq> <delim>required-item</delim> </groupseq> </syntaxdiagram>
required-item

Optional items appear below the main path. <syntaxdiagram> <groupseq> <delim>required-item</delim> </groupseq> <groupseq> <delim importance="optional">optional-item</delim> </groupseq> </syntaxdiagram>
required-item
optional-item

If an item appears above the main path, that item is a default; it takes effect if nothing else in that position is specified. <syntaxdiagram> <groupseq> <kwd importance="required">required-item</kwd> </groupseq> <groupseq> <kwd importance="default">default-item</kwd> </groupseq> </syntaxdiagram>
required-item
default-item

If more than one item can be chosen, they appear vertically, in a stack. <syntaxdiagram> <groupchoice> <kwd>optional-choice-1</kwd> <kwd>optional-choice-2</kwd> </groupchoice> </syntaxdiagram>
optional-choice-1 optional-choice-2
If one of the items must be chosen, one item of the stack appears on the main path. If choosing any of the items is optional, the group itself can be marked as optional, the entire stack then appears below the main path.
<syntaxdiagram> <groupchoice importance="optional"> <var>optional_choice</var> <var>optional_choice</var> </groupchoice> </syntaxdiagram>
optional_choice optional_choice
If one of the items is the default, it will appear above the main path and the remaining choices will be shown below.
<syntaxdiagram> <groupchoice importance="optional"> <var importance="default">default_choice</var> <var>optional_choice</var> <var>optional_choice</var> </groupchoice> </syntaxdiagram>
default_choice optional_choice optional_choice
If an optional item has a default when it is not specified, the default appears above the main path.
<syntaxdiagram> <groupseq> <var>required_item</var> </groupseq> <groupchoice importance="optional"> <groupseq> <var>optional_choice</var> <groupchoice importance="required"> <var importance="default">default_choice</var> <var>required_choice</var> <var>required_choice</var> </groupchoice> </groupseq> <var>optional_choice</var> </groupchoice> </syntaxdiagram>
required_item
optional_choice
default_choice required_choice required_choice
optional_choice
Note that if a group choice if more complex and contains items with their own path, then it takes pipes to separates items.
<syntaxdiagram> <groupseq> <var>required_item</var> </groupseq> <groupchoice importance="optional"> <groupseq> <var>optional_choice</var> <groupchoice importance="required"> <var importance="default">default_choice</var> <var>required_choice</var> <var>required_choice</var> </groupchoice> </groupseq> <groupseq> <var>optional_choice</var> <groupchoice importance="required"> <var importance="default">default_choice</var> <var>required_choice</var> <var>required_choice</var> </groupchoice> </groupseq> </groupchoice> </syntaxdiagram>
required_item
optional_choice
default_choice required_choice required_choice
optional_choice
default_choice required_choice required_choice

An arrow returning to the left, above the main line, indicates an item that can be repeated. <syntaxdiagram> <groupseq> <var>required_item</var> </groupseq> <groupseq> <repsep/> <var importance="required">repeatable_item</var> </groupseq> </syntaxdiagram>
required_item
repeatable_item
If the repeat arrow contains a comma, you must separate repeated items with a comma.
<syntaxdiagram> <groupseq> <var>required_item</var> </groupseq> <groupseq> <repsep>,</repsep> <var importance="required">repeatable_item</var> </groupseq> </syntaxdiagram>
required_item
, repeatable_item
A repeat arrow above a stack indicates that you can repeat the items in the stack.

The syntax diagrams only contain the preferred or standard keywords. If non-standard synonyms are supported in addition to the standard keywords, they are described in the Notes sections instead of the syntax diagrams. For maximum portability, only the preferred or standard keywords should be used.

Sometimes a single variable represents a larger fragment of the syntax. For example, in the following diagram, the variable parameter-block represents the whole syntax fragment that is labeled parameter-block : <syntaxdiagram> <groupseq> <var>required_item</var> </groupseq> <fragref>parameter-block</fragref> <fragment> <title>parameter-block</title> <groupchoice> <var>parameter1</var> <groupseq> <var>parameter2</var> <groupchoice> <var>parameter3</var> <var>parameter4</var> </groupchoice> </groupseq> </groupchoice> </fragment> </syntaxdiagram>
required_item
parameter-block
parameter-block
parameter1
parameter2
parameter3 parameter4

section.title: Implementation tests
section.p: Groupchoice with default importance. It doesn't make sense to set the whole group choice above the main path, because what would it really mean? What would the group resolve to without any actual choice from the user. This is why if the whole group has the default importance, the first entry in the group without optional or required importance will be used as default, unless there is some items explicitly set as default, in which case they will be used as default, and the default importance of the group has no effect.

Groupchoice as default for a group choice. The default importance attribute is caught be the parent group choice, which means the whole inner group choice will be default of the parent group choice, and the inner group doens't have a default since the attribute was already consumed by the parent group.

section.title: Test fragments
section.p: Test fragment reference by title
Test synnote
section.codeblock: <syntaxdiagram> <synnote>Some note at the beginning of the syntax diagram</synnote> <groupseq> <synnote>Some note at the beginning of a groupseq</synnote> <var>required_item</var> </groupseq> <groupchoice> <var>parameter1</var> <groupseq> <var>parameter2</var> <groupchoice> <synnote>This is a note at the beginning of a groupchoice</synnote> <var>parameter3</var> <var>parameter4</var> </groupchoice> </groupseq> </groupchoice> </syntaxdiagram>

syntaxdiagram.synnote: Some note at the beginning of the syntax diagram

groupseq.synnote: Some note at the beginning of a groupseq

groupchoice.synnote: This is a note at the beginning of a groupchoice

section.p: Basic test cases

One groupseq with few items. A group is a logical set of pieces of syntax that go together. Within the syntax definition, groups of keywords, delimiters and other syntax units act as a combined unit, and they occur in a specific sequence, as delimited by the <groupseq> element.

One groupchoice with few items. A group is a logical set of pieces of syntax that go together. A group choice specifies that the user must make a choice about which part of the syntax to use. Groups are often nested.

One groupccomp with few items. A group is a logical set of pieces of syntax that go together. The group composite means that the items that make up the syntax diagram will be formatted close together rather than being separated by a horizontal or vertical line, which is the usual formatting method.
two default
two required
two optional only
two optional and one without important attribute
two default
two required
two optional only
two optional and one without important attribute
two default
two required
two optional only
two optional and one without important attribute
If the groupchoice is optional, all choices go below the main path, even if one entry is tagged as default
If all items are required or nothing, then the first one goes on the main path, and others below:
If all items are optional, then same as the group itself being option, they all go below and nothing goes on the main path:
If one or more is default, the first default goes above the main path, others go below the main path:
section.codeblock:
<syntaxdiagram> <groupchoice> <var importance="optional">optional_1</var> <var importance="optional">optional_2</var> <var importance="optional">optional_3</var> <var importance="default">default_1</var> </groupchoice> </syntaxdiagram>
<syntaxdiagram> <groupchoice> <var importance="optional">optional_1</var> <var importance="optional">optional_2</var> <var importance="optional">optional_3</var> <var importance="default">default_1</var> <var importance="default">default_2</var> </groupchoice> </syntaxdiagram>
